awd_titl_txt: Why Do Active Regions Erupt?  Modeling of Active Region from Pre-Eruptive to Eruptive Processes
awd_abstract_narration:
Solar eruptions have significant impact on the near-Earth environment due to the enhanced flux of energetic particles bombarding the Earth and the embedded magnetic structures impacting the Earth's magnetosphere.  This has serious consequences for our technological assets both in space and on the ground, including interruption of tele-communication, compromising the safety of astronauts, and damaging satellites and electric power grids.  Therefore, focused investigations of solar eruptions and the associated magnetic field evolution of the solar corona have the potential to reveal the underlying physical mechanism(s) of the drivers of space weather at the Sun.  This 3-year project is aimed at investigating the physical origins of solar eruptions at the Sun by means of data-driven, three-dimensional (3-D) numerical simulations.  The project also has a strong educational component as it provides partial support for a Ph.D. student and a junior scientist at the University of Alabama in Huntsville.  Thus, the research and EPO agenda of this project supports the Strategic Goals of the AGS Division in discovery, learning, diversity, and interdisciplinary research.

This 3-year project is aimed at answering some of the fundamental questions concerning the physical origin and evolution of solar eruptions, which will expand the frontier of existing knowledge on the energy release during solar flares and Coronal Mass Ejections (CMEs) on the Sun and the associated reconfiguration of the solar corona.  The underlying research objectives are: (i) understanding the fundamental active region (AR) eruptive physics; and, (ii) providing a practical tool as an initiation model for the development of a physics-based data-driven space weather prediction code.  The research plan is to use the MHD-DARE model developed by the project team, together with observational data from the HMI and AIA instruments onboard the Solar Dynamics Observatory (SDO), to address the following science questions: (i) what are the basic characteristics of magnetic field configuration before a solar eruption?; (ii) how do photospheric surface motions, including shear, convergence and flux cancellation bring the initial emerged fields to such an unstable configuration?; (iii) what are the specific roles played by magnetic flux rope and magnetic reconnection in triggering solar eruptions?; (iv) can we understand the complexity of various flare/eruption process from topology and evolution of the magnetic field?; and, (v) how do solar eruptions leave imprints on the photospheric fields?  These aspects of the AR development will be connected to the evolution of the coronal field long before and during a solar eruption, for which the project team will use the MHD-DARE model to carry out numerical simulations driven by the time-dependent vector magnetograms.  Then, the simulation results will be analyzed to yield the evolution of the magnetic topology, electric currents, plasma flows, and Lorentz force to determine the primary triggering mechanisms of the solar eruption, and they will be compared with relevant solar observations.  In addition, the project team plans to further improve the current model by including a realistic energy equation and a plasma configuration directly from the photosphere into the solar corona.

por.por_cntn:
"Aurora borealis could be visible in wide swaths of continental US, Europe on Saturday because of large solar flare" - CNN, October 30, 2021. Have you ever wondered what's the science behind this headline news? Solar flare is one type of the most energetic eruptions from the Sun, often accompanied by rapid release of significant amounts of energy and mass. Such ejections of mass, so-called coronal mass ejections (CMEs), sometimes are hurling toward Earth, penetrating the shield of Earth's own magnetic field upon impact, causing a wide range of disturbances. These effects can last from hours to days, ranging from spectacular display of auroras to more detrimental disruptions of communication, navigation, and power grid systems in space and on the ground. Therefore there has been tremendous interest in and benefit for understanding the underlying physical cause and characteristics of these solar eruptions, namely, the solar flare and CMEs.

 

It is well understood that the solar magnetic field plays a critical role in energizing and propelling the solar eruptions, especially close to the Sun in the corona, immediately above the visible surface, the photosphere. In particular, the core structure embedded within a CME is generally believed to possess a configuration of a magnetic flux rope. Analogous to an ordinary rope with multiple threads, a magnetic flux rope is composed of multiple flux bundles (or magnetic field lines) that are intertwined and threading together, taking the shape of an elongated rope (or a twisted ribbon; see the image). Such a configuration can be formed during solar flare when coronal magnetic fields are constantly reshuffling. However such an important process involving magnetic field and the manifestation of a magnetic flux rope are rarely observed directly via space-borne and ground-based solar telescopes, because of the lack of capability of measuring the coronal magnetic field directly.

 

Efforts have been put into numerical modeling of coronal magnetic field configuration, especially that of a magnetic flux rope. This is similar to a lab experiment, except that everything is done with a computer to generate a "virtual reality" of the Sun, or in particular, the solar active regions (ARs), where the solar magnetic field concentrates and solar eruptions are more likely to originate. We have developed and employed multiple numerical simulation codes to reveal the topological features and temporal evolutions of ARs. We recovered several features that correspond well to other types of complementary observations and are important for pre-conditioning of subsequent eruptions. We found that a magnetic flux rope may not exist prior to a CME eruption, but can be formed during or upon the eruption, often accompanying the corresponding solar flare.

 

The study of magnetic flux ropes is also extended beyond the vicinity of the Sun. When a CME erupts and propagates away from the Sun into the interplanetary space, carrying the embedded magnetic field structure, it can be intercepted by a spacecraft at larger distances. For example, there are a number of spacecraft missions around the Earth. Therefore in addition to remote-sensing observations, these spacecraft can also provide in-situ measurements of the interplanetary medium, including the magnetic field, fluid properties and discrete particle populations of the surrounding medium. These direct measurements are employed to examine the magnetic flux rope structures through quantitative means, over a wide range of scales. We found that the magnetic flux rope configuration embedded in CMEs is confirmed by the in-situ measurements. By relating these structures to their solar source region properties, a better understanding of the origination of these structures can be achieved. In addition, we also found that there exists a wealth of magnetic flux rope structures in interplanetary space (for more technical details, see http://fluxrope.info). Their origin and consequences have yet to be further explored.

 

Overall it has been a fun and fulfilling journey. Along the way, two Master's theses and two PhD dissertations were completed. We are grateful for the continuous support from the agency and the public. We hope that these outcomes will have long-lasting impact for generations to come.
